text.p: Suppose that [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^5 \rightarrow \mathbb R^7[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation. Suppose further that we can find two vectors [mathjaxinline]v,w \in \mathbb R^5[/mathjaxinline], neither of which is a scalar multiple of the other, such that [mathjaxinline]T(v) = T(w) = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline].
What is the strongest conclusion we can make about the rank of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?

p.p: The rank of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is at least

font.p: We have [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]w[/mathjaxinline] as linearly independent vectors in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {Ker}(T).[/mathjaxinline] Therefore the nullity of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is at least 2. Since the nullity plus rank must equal 5, that means the rank is at most 3.
